A decision or order of the director on a matter in respect of which the director has exclusive jurisdiction is final and conclusive and is not open to question or review in any court.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Certain director's orders may be filed in Provincial Court

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies to a decision or an order of the director if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the decision or order is for financial compensation or the return of personal property, and
the amount required to be paid under the decision or order, excluding interest and costs, or the value of the personal property is within the monetary limit for claims under the Small Claims Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A decision or an order described in subsection (1) may be filed in the Provincial Court and enforced as a judgment or an order of that court after

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a review of the director's decision or order has been

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: refused or dismissed, or
concluded, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the time period to apply for a review has expired.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The director may conduct investigations to ensure compliance with this Act and the regulations whether or not the director has accepted an application for dispute resolution in relation to the matter.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director may require a person to provide to the director, within a reasonable time, all records in the person's possession or control related in any way to an investigation.
A person required under subsection (1) to provide records must comply with the requirement.
Subject to the regulations, the director may order a person to pay a monetary penalty if the director is satisfied on a balance of probabilities that the person has

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: contravened a provision of this Act or the regulations,
failed to comply with a decision or order of the director, or a demand issued by the director for production of records, or
given false or misleading information in a dispute resolution proceeding or an investigation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before the director imposes an administrative penalty on a person, the director must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: give the person an opportunity to be heard, and
consider all the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: previous enforcement actions for contraventions of a similar nature by the person;
the gravity and magnitude of the contravention;
the extent of the harm to others resulting from the contravention;
whether the contravention was repeated or continuous;
whether the contravention was deliberate;
any economic benefit derived by the person from the contravention;
the person's efforts to correct the contravention.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A penalty imposed under this section must be paid within the prescribed time.
Instead of enforcing a penalty under subsection (1), the director, subject to the regulations, may enter into an agreement with the person who would otherwise be liable for the penalty.

An agreement under subsection (4) may provide, in accordance with the regulations, for the reduction or cancellation of the penalty subject to the terms and conditions the director considers necessary or desirable.

An agreement under subsection (4) must specify the time for performing the terms and conditions and, if the person fails to perform those terms and conditions by the date specified, the penalty ordered under subsection (1) is due and payable on the date of the failure.

Neither the director's decision whether to enter into an agreement under subsection (4), nor the terms and conditions of such an agreement, may be the subject of an application for dispute resolution.

If a corporation contravenes the Act or the regulations or fails to comply with a decision or order as described under subsection (1), an employee, officer, director or agent of the corporation who authorized, permitted or acquiesced in the contravention or failure is also liable under this section even though the corporation is liable for or pays a monetary penalty under this section.
A monetary penalty imposed under section 80.3 (1) may not exceed $5 000.

If a contravention or failure referred to in section 80.3 (1) occurs over more than one day or continues for more than one day, separate monetary penalties, each not exceeding the maximum under subsection (1) of this section, may be imposed for each day the contravention or failure continues.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If the director imposes an administrative penalty on a person, the director must give to the person a notice specifying each of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the contravention, failure or false or misleading information to which the penalty relates;
the amount of the penalty;
the date by which the penalty must be paid;
the person's right to have the director reconsider the decision imposing the penalty.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A decision of the director under this Part must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be in writing,
be signed and dated by the director, and
include the reasons for the decision.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as otherwise provided in this Part, a decision or an order of the director under this Part is final and binding on the person subject to the decision or order.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Correction or clarification of decisions or orders

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director may, with or without a hearing,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: correct typographic, grammatical, arithmetic or other similar errors in the director's decision or order,
clarify the decision or order, and
deal with an obvious error or inadvertent omission in the decision or order.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director may take the steps described in subsection (1)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on the director's own initiative, or
at the request of the person subject to the decision or order, which request, for subsection (1) (b) and (c), must be made within 15 days after the decision or order is received.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director must not act under this section unless the director considers it just and reasonable to do so in all the circumstances.
A person who receives a notice under section 80.5 may apply to the director for a review of the matters set out in the notice.
The director may, on the director's own initiative, review the matters set out in the notice.
Subject to subsection (4), Division 2 [Review of Decisions and Orders] of Part 6 applies to a review under this section.
For the purposes of this section, section 72 (2) is to be read as if it provided that a decision or order of the director may be reviewed only on one or more of the following grounds:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person was unable to be heard because of circumstances that could not be anticipated and were beyond the person's control;
the person has new and relevant evidence that was not available before the director imposed the administrative penalty and that materially affects the decision to impose the administrative penalty;

a person who performed administrative tasks for the director made a procedural error that materially affected the decision to impose the administrative penalty or the amount of the administrative penalty;
a technical irregularity or error occurred that materially affected the decision to impose an administrative penalty or the amount of the administrative penalty;
the director did not determine an issue that the director was required to determine.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An administrative penalty imposed under this Division is a debt due to the government.

If a person fails to pay an administrative penalty as required by a notice under section 80.5 and the time for requesting a review under section 80.8 has expired, the director may file a certificate in the Supreme Court or the Provincial Court and, on filing, the certificate has the same force and effect, and all proceedings may be taken on it, as if it were a judgment of the court with which it is filed.
A certificate under subsection (2) must be in the approved form, be signed by the director and set out

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the name of the person who is liable for the penalty,
the contravention, failure or false or misleading information in relation to which the penalty is imposed, and
the amount of the penalty.

bcl:division.bcl:text: How to Give or Serve Records

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: How to give or serve records generally
bcl:section.bcl:text: All records, other than those referred to in section 82 [special rules for certain records], that are required or permitted under this Act to be given to or served on a person must be given or served in one of the following ways:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by leaving a copy with the person;
if the person is a landlord, by leaving a copy with an agent of the landlord;
by sending a copy by ordinary mail or registered mail to the address at which the person resides or, if the person is a landlord, to the address at which the person carries on business as a landlord;
if the person is a tenant, by sending a copy by ordinary mail or registered mail to a forwarding address provided by the tenant;
by leaving a copy at the person's residence with an adult who apparently resides with the person;
by leaving a copy in a mailbox or mail slot for the address at which the person resides or, if the person is a landlord, for the address at which the person carries on business as a landlord;

by attaching a copy to a door or other conspicuous place at the address at which the person resides or, if the person is a landlord, at the address at which the person carries on business as a landlord;
by transmitting a copy to a fax number provided as an address for service by the person to be served;
by any other means of service provided for in the regulations.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An application for dispute resolution or a decision of the director to proceed with a review under Division 2 of Part 6, when required to be given to one party by another, must be given in one of the following ways:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by leaving a copy with the person;
if the person is a landlord, by leaving a copy with an agent of the landlord;
by sending a copy by registered mail to the address at which the person resides or, if the person is a landlord, to the address at which the person carries on business as a landlord;
if the person is a tenant, by sending a copy by registered mail to a forwarding address provided by the tenant;
by any other means of service provided for in the regulations.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An application by a landlord under section 48 [order of possession for the landlord], 49 [application for order ending tenancy early] or 49.1 [order of possession: tenancy frustrated] must be given to the tenant in one of the following ways:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by leaving a copy with the tenant;
by sending a copy by registered mail to the address at which the tenant resides;
by leaving a copy at the tenant's residence with an adult who apparently resides with the tenant;
by attaching a copy to a door or other conspicuous place at the address at which the tenant resides;
by any other means of service provided for in the regulations.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A notice given under section 80.5 [notice of administrative penalty] must be given in one of the following ways:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by leaving a copy with the person or the person's agent;
if the person is a tenant, by sending a copy by registered mail to a forwarding address provided by the tenant;
if the person is a tenant, landlord or any other person, by sending a copy by registered mail to the address at which

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the person resides or carries on business, or
the person's agent carries on business;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if permitted by the regulations, by a means provided for in section 81 [how to give or serve records generally];
by another means provided for in the regulations.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: When records are considered to have been received
bcl:section.bcl:text: A record given or served in accordance with section 81 [how to give or serve records generally] or 82 [special rules for certain records], unless earlier received, is deemed to be received as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if given or served by mail, on the fifth day after it is mailed;
if given or served by fax, on the third day after it is faxed;
if given or served by attaching a copy of the record to a door or other place, on the third day after it is attached;
if given or served by leaving a copy of the record in a mailbox or mail slot, on the third day after it is left.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Except as modified or varied under this Act, the common law respecting landlords and tenants applies in British Columbia.
The Frustrated Contract Act and the doctrine of frustration of contract apply to tenancy agreements.

Despite any other enactment, no order of a court in a proceeding involving a foreclosure, an estate or a matrimonial dispute or another proceeding that affects possession of a manufactured home site is enforceable against a tenant of the manufactured home site unless the tenant was a party to the proceeding.
[Renumbered as 80.3 by 2017-18-16.]
[Renumbered as 80.4 by 2017-18-18.]
[Renumbered as 80.5 by 2017-18-19.]
[Renumbered as 80.8 by 2017-18-20.]
[Renumbered as 80.9 by 2017-18-21.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who contravenes any of the following provisions commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine of not more than $5 000:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: section 13 (1), (2) or (3) [requirements for tenancy agreements];
section 15 [no application or processing fees];
section 17 (2) [no security deposit];
section 20 (3) [seizing or interfering with access to tenant's property];
section 21 (1) [terminating or restricting services or facilities];
section 23 [landlord's right to enter a manufactured home site restricted];
section 24 (1) or (2) [tenant's right of access protected];
section 25 (1) [prohibitions on changes to locks];
section 28 (3) [assignment and subletting];
section 35 (1) and (2) [timing and notice of rent increases];
section 36 (1) [amount of rent increase];
section 50 (2) [what happens if a tenant does not leave when tenancy ended].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who coerces, threatens, intimidates or harasses a tenant or landlord

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in order to deter the tenant or landlord from making an application under this Act, or
in retaliation for seeking or obtaining a remedy under this Act

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine of not more than $5 000.
A person who contravenes or fails to comply with a decision or an order made by the director commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine of not more than $5 000.
A person who gives false or misleading information in a proceeding under this Act commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine of not more than $5 000.

A tenant, or a person permitted in the manufactured home park by a tenant, who intentionally, recklessly or negligently causes damage to the manufactured home park commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine of not more than $5 000.

If a person convicted of an offence under this Act has failed to comply with or contravened this Act, the court, in addition to imposing a fine, may order the person to comply with or to cease contravening this Act.
Section 5 of the Offence Act does not apply to this Act or the regulations.
A prosecution of an offence under this Act must not be commenced more than 2 years after the facts on which the proceeding is based first come to the knowledge of the director.
A record purporting to have been issued by the director, certifying the date on which the director became aware of the facts on which the information is based,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is admissible without proof of the signature or official character of the person appearing to have signed the certificate, and
is proof of the certified facts unless there is evidence to the contrary.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations referred to in section 41 of the Interpretation Act.
Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: exempting tenancy agreements, manufactured home sites or manufactured home parks from all or part of this Act;
prescribing the circumstances in which a landlord may include in a fixed term tenancy agreement a requirement that the tenant vacate a manufactured home site at the end of the term;
respecting tenancy agreements, including prescribing

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: standard terms that must be included in every tenancy agreement, and
formal requirements for tenancy agreements;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: respecting rights and obligations of landlords and tenants that are not inconsistent with this Act, and providing that those rights and obligations must be terms of tenancy agreements;
prescribing a penalty for a breach of a regulation, subject to the restriction that the penalty must not be greater than the maximum penalty referred to in section 87 [offences and penalties];
prescribing

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the circumstances in which a landlord may consider that a tenant has abandoned personal property,
the manner in which a landlord may dispose of personal property abandoned by a tenant, and
how competing claims on the property are to be resolved;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prescribing

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the circumstances in which the purchaser of abandoned personal property acquires a marketable title free of all encumbrances,
how proceeds from disposing of the property are to be dealt with, and
imposing a duty of care on the landlord for that property;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prescribing the circumstances in which a landlord may not claim reimbursement from a tenant if the proceeds from disposing of a manufactured home abandoned by the tenant are not sufficient to reimburse the landlord for the cost of disposition, or satisfy any other amount payable to the landlord, as provided for in a regulation made under paragraph (e) or (f);
prescribing matters related to an assignment of a tenancy agreement or a sublease of a manufactured home site, including

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the process for obtaining the landlord's consent to an assignment or a sublease,
the procedures for determining whether that consent is given or withheld and related matters, and
the circumstances in which a landlord may withhold consent to an assignment or a sublease;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: respecting the return of trust funds collected under section 58 (1) (a) [director's orders: breach of Act, regulations or tenancy agreement], including prescribing the circumstances in which interest must be paid on the trust funds and how that interest is to be calculated;
defining a word or phrase used but not defined in this Act;
respecting matters related to reviews under Division 2 of Part 6;
respecting refundable and non-refundable fees that a landlord may or may not impose on a tenant and limiting the amount of a fee that may be imposed;
respecting park committees, including

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: prescribing procedures for establishing park committees, selecting members and making rules, and
respecting the participation of a park committee in voluntary dispute resolution;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: respecting

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the procedures a landlord must follow to establish, change or repeal a park rule, and
the frequency with which a landlord may establish, change or repeal a park rule;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: respecting the security a landlord may require when a tenant is moving a manufactured home onto or off a manufactured home site;
prescribing fees for anything done or any service provided under this Act;
prescribing calculations for rent increases under section 36 (1) (a) [amount of rent increase];

respecting rent increases that may be approved by the director under section 62 [director's orders: rent increases] on application under section 36 (3) [amount of rent increase], including, without limitation,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: prescribing circumstances for the purposes of section 36 (3),
prescribing calculations for rent increases under section 62,
prescribing rules respecting the application of rent increases under section 62, and
respecting the maximum rent increase that may be approved by the director under section 62;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prescribing an amount as compensation payable under section 44 (1), which amount may not be more than the monetary limit for claims under the Small Claims Act;
prescribing an amount as compensation payable under section 44 (2), which amount may not be more than the monetary limit for claims under the Small Claims Act;
respecting means of giving or serving records, including

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: providing for different means of giving or serving records for different purposes, to the director or to different classes of persons, and
prescribing when records given or served by those means are deemed to be received;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: respecting administrative penalties, including, without limitation,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: establishing procedures for providing an opportunity to be heard for the purposes of section 80.3 (2) (a), which need not entail an oral hearing,
establishing procedures for providing an opportunity to object to a demand for production of records,

prescribing consequences for failing to appear or provide submissions, as applicable, on an opportunity prescribed under subparagraph (i), which may include, but are not limited to, proceeding in the absence of the person who fails to appear or without their submission, as applicable,
prescribing time limits for paying administrative penalties,
the matters that must be considered by the director in establishing a penalty in a particular case,
prescribing a limitation period for imposing an administrative penalty and evidentiary matters in relation to that period,
respecting agreements, including prescribing terms and conditions that must be included in an agreement under section 80.3 (4), and
establishing consequences for failing to pay an administrative penalty which may include, but are not limited to, imposing additional penalties;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for any other purpose for which regulations are contemplated by this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In making regulations under this Act, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: delegate a matter to a person,
confer a discretion on a person, and

make different regulations for different manufactured home sites, manufactured home parks or tenancy agreements or for different classes of manufactured home sites, manufactured home parks or tenancy agreements.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: repealing the definition of "cannabis control date" in section 18.1, and
amending section 18.1 (2) and (4) to replace references to the cannabis control date with the date that section 14 of the Cannabis Control and Licensing Act comes into force.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Part, former Act means the Residential Tenancy Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 406.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A landlord who holds a security deposit under the former Act in respect of a tenancy agreement to which this Act applies, despite section 17 (2) [security deposits], may hold that security deposit until the end of the tenancy.
The following sections of the Residential Tenancy Act apply in respect of a security deposit referred to in subsection (1):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: section 19 [limits on amount];
section 20 (a), (b) and (e) [landlord prohibitions];
section 21 [tenant prohibition];
section 38 [return of security deposit];
section 39 [if forwarding address not provided];
section 72 (2) (b) [director's orders: fees and monetary orders];
section 93 [obligations pass with transfer or assignment of land].

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Transitional: agreements under Part 5 of former Act
bcl:section.bcl:text: A term of an agreement referred to in section 71 (1), (2) or (5) of the former Act is considered to be a term of the tenancy agreement of the landlord and tenant who made the agreement or who are deemed to have made the agreement and the term may be enforced under this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations considered necessary or advisable to more effectively bring this Act into operation and to facilitate the transition from the operation of the former Act to the operation of this Act, including regulations prescribing the manner in which any transitional question or issue arising because of the repeal of the former Act is to be resolved.

The Lieutenant Governor in Council, by regulation, may amend the following sections of this Act by striking out "the date this section comes into force" and substituting the actual date the applicable section comes into force:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: section 12 (a) [tenancy agreements include the standard terms];
section 13 (1) [requirements for tenancy agreements].
[Repealed B.C. Reg. 389/2007.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a fixed term tenancy agreement entered into before this section comes into force requires that a tenant must vacate the manufactured home site on a specified date, the requirement to vacate the manufactured home site ceases to have effect as of the date this section comes into force, except

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the tenancy agreement is a sublease agreement,
if circumstances prescribed under section 89 (2) (a.1) apply, or
if, before the day this Act receives First Reading in the Legislative Assembly,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the landlord entered into a tenancy agreement, to begin after the expiry of an existing tenancy agreement that includes a requirement to vacate the manufactured home site, with a new tenant for the manufactured home site, or
the director granted an order of possession to the landlord on the basis of a requirement to vacate the manufactured home site in an existing tenancy agreement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of enforcing a requirement that remains in effect under subsection (1), sections 37 and 48 continue to apply as they read immediately before this section comes into force.

bcl:section.bcl:text: This Act comes into force by regulation of the Lieutenant Governor in Council.
